shortDescription: The Dragon-Slaying Lance of Saint George
name: Ascalon

extendedContent.content:
Ascalon is the name traditionally given to the lance or spear wielded by Saint
                    George in his legendary battle against the dragon. While the weapon is not named
                    in the earliest versions of the Saint George legend, later medieval traditions
                    gave it this name, possibly derived from the city of Ashkelon in the Levant,
                    where George was said to have originated.
                
                
                    The lance represents the archetypal weapon of the Christian knight - the primary
                    arm of a mounted warrior, used to strike the first and often decisive blow in
                    combat. In Saint George's hands, Ascalon became a symbol of faith's power to
                    overcome evil, the physical manifestation of spiritual warfare.
                
                
                    Unlike many legendary weapons that possess magical properties, Ascalon's power
                    in Christian tradition comes not from enchantment but from the righteousness
                    of its wielder and the blessing of God. It is a mortal weapon made sacred
                    through holy purpose.
extendedContent.title: Description and Nature

extendedContent.content:
The Dragon and the Princess
                
                    According to the most popular version of the legend (found in Jacobus de
                    Voragine's Golden Legend, c. 1260), a fearsome dragon lived near the city
                    of Silene in Libya (or sometimes Beirut or Cappadocia, depending on the
                    version). The dragon poisoned the countryside and demanded daily sacrifices
                    of sheep to appease its hunger.
                
                
                    When sheep grew scarce, the city began sacrificing humans, selected by lot.
                    One day the lot fell upon the king's daughter. Despite the king's pleas,
                    the princess was led to the dragon's lake to await her fate.
                

                Saint George's Intervention
                
                    George, a Roman soldier from Cappadocia and a Christian knight, happened upon
                    the princess awaiting the dragon. Learning of her plight, he resolved to
                    confront the monster. When the dragon emerged, George charged on horseback,
                    making the sign of the cross and commending himself to God.
                
                
                    With Ascalon, George struck the dragon a grievous blow, wounding it severely.
                    He then had the princess tie her girdle around the dragon's neck, and the
                    beast followed them meekly into the city. There, George promised to slay
                    the dragon if the people would convert to Christianity. When they agreed,
                    he killed the beast with his sword, and the king built a church on the spot.
extendedContent.title: The Legend of Saint George

extendedContent.content:
Triumph of Faith Over Evil
                
                    Ascalon represents the power of Christian faith to overcome evil. The dragon
                    in medieval Christian symbolism often represented Satan, paganism, or sin
                    itself. George's victory with Ascalon thus symbolizes the triumph of the
                    Church over its spiritual enemies.
                

                Chivalric Ideal
                
                    The lance of Saint George became the archetypal weapon of the ideal Christian
                    knight - the miles Christi or "soldier of Christ." Ascalon embodies the
                    chivalric virtues of courage, faith, and protection of the innocent that
                    medieval culture celebrated.
                

                National Symbolism
                
                    As Saint George became the patron saint of England, Portugal, Georgia, and
                    numerous other nations and cities, his lance became associated with national
                    identity. The image of George with Ascalon appears on coats of arms, flags,
                    and national symbolism throughout Europe.
                

                The Knight's Weapon
                
                    The choice of a lance rather than a sword for George's dragon-slaying reflects
                    the medieval understanding of martial hierarchy. The lance was the knight's
                    primary weapon, the one used for the initial charge that decided battles.
                    George's use of Ascalon marks him as a true knight.
extendedContent.title: Symbolism and Significance
Modern Depictions
extendedContent.content:
Guild Wars 2: Features Ascalon as a significant location
                    and Ascalonian weapons as a weapon set
                    Various RPGs: Saint George's lance appears as a holy
                    weapon effective against dragons and evil
                    Heraldry: The image of George with his lance remains
                    common in English, Georgian, and other national symbolism
                    Religious Art: Countless paintings, sculptures, and
                    icons depict George with Ascalon piercing the dragon
